title: Yasuo's huge ban wave worries me about the future of balancing...
body: Unfortunately all over the place people have been complaining about yasuo for a very long time and it has been ignored because pro's don't play him. At last this huge ban wave against him has caused riot to pay attention to him but also sends a message. Is this what we have to do now to get a champion to be balanced? Perma ban them? Make it so people just can't play the champion? This is wrong... yet it works. I hope there's better ways in the future.

replies.body:
Hmm. That's an interesting perspective, because I had the opposite reaction.

I realized that 10 bans gives the balance team good incentive to look at champs that are frustrating to play against. I share the opinion with many that Yasuo is NOT overpowered. I do, though, admit that he isn't fun for the opponent at all. 

If that's what has to happen to make it a priority... oh well. Now we have 10 bans, so any champion in that boat will move up the priority list. To me, that sounds like "problem solved."

There's two sides to every coin, I suppose.

I disagree. Everyone should be able to ban what they hate. When enough people hate something, it becomes an issue, and the developers are forced to fix the champion lest the copious money poured into the champion's design go to waste.

10 bans provides a reasonable bandaid when the community is waiting for Riot to fix something, and simultaneously gives a good metric to measure hatred of given champions.
Additionally, if they fix the champion, they'll achieve lower ban rates, and the game will be more enjoyable for the previously cancerous champion's mains, and for the players who have to play against (or with) them.
if you stamp your feet hard enough riot will appease you

You remember when Kassadin was 100% pick/ban in Season 3 and 4? Mmh, delicious times. He was nerfed into the ground in Season 5, so we can at least hope for the same with Yas. 

But yeah, this has been a trend since the beginning. No worries, man.

The difference here though is that Yasuo, unlike Kassadin at that time, is not overpowered or dominating the meta. His ban rate is almost exclusively motivated by a memory/confirmation bias of his "annoying kit" and "feeding on my team" "carries on enemy team".

Not to say that I don't think Yasuo lacks a bit of agency, mainly with Windwall size/duration in my opinion, but he honestly, from a game play standpoint, isn't worth the ban, strictly based on the number of champions you can pick to easily shut him down. 

I am glad they are going to look at Yasuo. I hope they will achieve making him feel better to play against, and also succeed in making him an ACTUALLY strong champion, because I love his champion concept.

These Kassadin/Yasuo equivocation posts irritate me to no end. Kass had a 99% banrate at all elos and was 100% pick or ban in pro play during that entire time. Yasuo has been picked or banned 1 single time in pro play so far this season, and his banrate also drops off a cliff as elo rises. Yasuo isn't Kassadin. Yasuo is Feral Flare Master Yi circa Season 4.

This isn't about Yasuo being op, its about his kit being overloaded.  The reason why people hate him isn't simply because people hate playing against him, its because people hate playing with him...considering all the bads who pick him because his kit is publicly known to be overloaded.

He feeds the other team if you're a bad, gets fed and snowballs and makes the game decidedly easy if he's not bad.  He is simply way too safe to play aggressive with because of the overloaded kit which makes him attractive to bad players who don't know how to retreat and thus end up feeding.  

The snowballing is the other issue and that's opponents laning against bad players who will inevitably will be on your team....but if there is more risk added to his kit as in increased cooldown for e and shield nerf I guarantee you he wont be so hated.  The whole 'lrn to play against him' is the weakest argument you can make because it simply ignores the problem everyone knows is there.

This nonsense is exactly why I was against 10 bans from the start because it basically allows the playerbase to hold a champion hostage and demand that Riot either gut or rework them by permabanning that champ until they do. I play in high enough elo that most people aren't scared shitless of Yasuo but anyone gold and below is pretty much out of luck.

I'm just curious who the community will target next once they succeed in ruining Yasuo. Leblanc? Fizz? Zed? Zac?

10 bans was the best thing we could get.

If a champion isn't OP and still banned that often then something's inherently wrong with it. Where Riot refused to (or simply didn't think it was important enough to) listen before the new bans the players can now force them to take a look at it.

To this end, it's a bad idea to use a high percentage of bans as a reason for making balance changes, as it doesn't accurately show whether a champion is strong or over bearing, just that people think they are.

After having yasuo free for 2 weeks, I played him somewhat but honestly loved playing against those who didn't own him. As with any champion, if you put in the practice to play a champion to an excellent standard, you will generally play matchups very well. I played yasuo more than I needed to when I bought him almost a year ago in nearly every ranked game. Against opponents who were truly better at their champions, I never won a single matchups. In games where the other players maybe have excellent technical skill and champion skills, but little teamwork, coordination and map control, I could just farm and push down towers, maybe inserting myself into very one sided teamfights. It's really a matter of how well you play him.

It would be better if Riot actually did an effort to detect unbalanced champions and try to solve the balance problems, but Riot's policy about Yasuo has been "if no one plays him in the Corean high leagues he is not a problem". 

If we have to permaban a champion so Riot sees there is a problem, I'm fine with it. Yasuo has had an overloaded and toxic skillset for years and Riot mostly ignored the problem; that tells you something about Riot's way of balancing.

Yasuo is balanced. He's tough to play, tough to play against. He's got lots of resources. He's a prettyboy samurai, high profile VA, good lines, some weeaboo Nippon thrown in there. He's got a huge katana, he has poke, he gets great damage early off far less gold than others. He can contribute to teamfights while behind and end them abruptly while ahead. He enjoys a solid solo experience but absolutely gobbles up synergy.

Now assume three people played a champion, do you think you'd get a lot? Probably not. But if hundreds of thousands play him and want to play him and play against him? All of a sudden you have this funny number bias. Just because he's popular, things seem so skewed. But realistically, he's not really that different than others. And if it wasn't him? {{champion:51}} {{champion:103}} {{champion:67}} {{champion:64}}  Just a smattering of champions who have historically been as popular as Yasuo for hate-on. If he weren't popular enough to garner this kind of attention ({{champion:6}} ) for any reason, he wouldn't get picks; he wouldn't get bans; then, nobody would talk about his balance, whether it existed or not.

Ahri's been the exact same champion design for a long time. As the meta evolves, she seems to get a change one season, which reverts, then another, and a revert. They lastly added her Q MS. Anyway, people have always hated Ahri. Too strong, too fast, too bursty, too much CC for an assassin, you know the drill. Fact is, her design's been the exact same except maybe level order and rotation, since she stepped off the plate to my knowledge. And people have always hated her. That's because they see her a ton; Galio got reworked and now people see him, and now people hate him. Nobody barely talked about Galio before; not as destroyed as Morde was, and not as clunky as old Sion was, he was pretty much a 'yeah, he could use a touch' almost any time he came up. They modernized his kit to have mobility and hey-- look. People hate him now.

People don't like a lot of things. But if Riot starts balancing, deciding things, based on what does and doesn't hurt some peoples' feelings in lane, their champ design is going to go to absolute garbage. Nobody has to like Yasuo. They don't even have to admit that he's balanced. He just has to be; and as long as he's balanced, he can get perma-banned from 99 games of a 100 and it's still just fine. The essence of balance is, 'can it be beaten in a standard scenario?' Not, 'do people like this?'

If it were something like 15 or 20% of the cast that suffered like Yasuo? Sure. But it's a handful of champions, and most actual balance discussions end in people screaming and swearing about how much they don't like facing opponents who defeat them, because they won't **DODGE THE GOD DAMN LUX Q IT'S LITERALLY A STRAIGHT LINE!**
